text: The power couple of Canon’s mirrorless lineup! The EOS R5 and EOS R6 are both power-packed, full-frame mirrorless interchangeable-lens cameras that have many photographers and enthusiasts drool since their release in 2020. How do they stack up against each other you ask? Let’s deconstruct these legends and see which one might be your next shutterbug companion.Canon R6 vs R5: Spec ShowdownFirst things first, let’s put down the specs and see where each camera flexes its muscles.Sensor and ResolutionFeatureCanon EOS R5Canon EOS R6Sensor45 MP Full-Frame CMOS20.1 MP Full-Frame CMOSImage ProcessorDIGIC XDIGIC XA top competitor for Canon’s best mirrorless camera for portraits and landscapes, the R5 boasts a whopping 45-megapixel sensor. In comparison the R6, with its 20.1 megapixels, might appear humbled, but don’t be misled. It’s still a full-frame sensor proficiently delivering stunning images, and its lower resolution can have an upper hand in low-light situations.Video CapabilitiesFeatureCanon EOS R5Canon EOS R6Video ResolutionUp to 8K at 30fpsUp to 4K at 60fpsSlow Motion4K at 120fps1080p at 120fpsThe R5’s 8K video capabilities are almost impossible to ignore If you’re a videographer with an appetite for UHD(ultra-high-definition). While not reaching those dizzying heights, the R6 still offers impressive 4K recording at 60fps, making it an excellent choice for most video applications.Autofocus and Image StabilizationBoth models provide swift and accurate autofocus performance as they feature Canon’s Dual Pixel CMOS AF II system and come fully equipped with in-body image stabilization (IBIS) offering up to 8 stops of correction, which is always a big ask for handheld shooting.Build and HandlingFeatureCanon EOS R5Canon EOS R6Body MaterialMagnesium AlloyMagnesium Alloy with PolycarbonateWeightApproximately 738gApproximately 675gThe R5’s magnesium alloy body gives you that premium feel, while the R6, with its blend of magnesium alloy and polycarbonate, is still premium and a tad bit lighter. Both being weather-sealed, they ensure safety and durability in various shooting conditions.Show Me the Money: Current Market PricesAs of March 2025, here’s how the pricing breaks down:CameraPriceCanon EOS R5Approximately $2,999.99 Canon EOS R6Approximately $2,499.00Reflecting its advanced features, the R5 commands a higher price tag, while in comparison the R6 offers a more budget-friendly option without compromising a whole lot on its performance.Purchasing OptionsHigh-Resolution ImageryThe R5’s 45MP sensor provides the detail you crave if your needs are large-format printing or heavy cropping. However, bear in mind that higher resolution means larger file sizes, which can be a storage concern and sometimes a hassle.Low-Light PerformanceThe lower-resolution sensor in the R6 can offer better low-light performance, making it a perfect choice in any scenario where the lighting isn’t ideal like weddings for example.Video ProductionThe R5’s 8K video opens up possibilities for high-resolution footage and flexibility in post-production in strong favour for filmmakers. The R6’s 4K capabilities are still flavorful, suitable for most content creation needs.The Verdict: A Matter of PreferenceIt’s more about aligning the camera’s strengths with your photographic needs and not all about specs and price when choosing between the R5 and R6. If what you need is high-resolution images and advanced video features, the R5 is worth its price and investment. If excellent performance at a more accessible price point better suits your situation, the R6 won’t disappoint.Finally, the best camera is always the one that fits your shooting style and helps you capture your vision. Happy shooting! When you purchase through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Here's how it works.
html:
The power couple of Canon’s mirrorless lineup! The EOS R5 and EOS R6 are both power-packed, full-frame mirrorless interchangeable-lens cameras that have many photographers and enthusiasts drool since their release in 2020. How do they stack up against each other you ask? Let’s deconstruct these legends and see which one might be your next shutterbug companion.

Canon R6 vs R5: Spec Showdown

First things first, let’s put down the specs and see where each camera flexes its muscles.

Sensor and Resolution

A top competitor for Canon’s best mirrorless camera for portraits and landscapes, the R5 boasts a whopping 45-megapixel sensor. In comparison the R6, with its 20.1 megapixels, might appear humbled, but don’t be misled. It’s still a full-frame sensor proficiently delivering stunning images, and its lower resolution can have an upper hand in low-light situations.

Video Capabilities

The R5’s 8K video capabilities are almost impossible to ignore If you’re a videographer with an appetite for UHD(ultra-high-definition). While not reaching those dizzying heights, the R6 still offers impressive 4K recording at 60fps, making it an excellent choice for most video applications.

Autofocus and Image Stabilization

Both models provide swift and accurate autofocus performance as they feature Canon’s Dual Pixel CMOS AF II system and come fully equipped with in-body image stabilization (IBIS) offering up to 8 stops of correction, which is always a big ask for handheld shooting.

Build and Handling

The R5’s magnesium alloy body gives you that premium feel, while the R6, with its blend of magnesium alloy and polycarbonate, is still premium and a tad bit lighter. Both being weather-sealed, they ensure safety and durability in various shooting conditions.

Show Me the Money: Current Market Prices

As of March 2025, here’s how the pricing breaks down:

Reflecting its advanced features, the R5 commands a higher price tag, while in comparison the R6 offers a more budget-friendly option without compromising a whole lot on its performance.

Purchasing Options

High-Resolution Imagery

The R5’s 45MP sensor provides the detail you crave if your needs are large-format printing or heavy cropping. However, bear in mind that higher resolution means larger file sizes, which can be a storage concern and sometimes a hassle.

Low-Light Performance

The lower-resolution sensor in the R6 can offer better low-light performance, making it a perfect choice in any scenario where the lighting isn’t ideal like weddings for example.

Video Production

The R5’s 8K video opens up possibilities for high-resolution footage and flexibility in post-production in strong favour for filmmakers. The R6’s 4K capabilities are still flavorful, suitable for most content creation needs.

The Verdict: A Matter of Preference

It’s more about aligning the camera’s strengths with your photographic needs and not all about specs and price when choosing between the R5 and R6. If what you need is high-resolution images and advanced video features, the R5 is worth its price and investment. If excellent performance at a more accessible price point better suits your situation, the R6 won’t disappoint.

Finally, the best camera is always the one that fits your shooting style and helps you capture your vision. Happy shooting!
